Derek James wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
>  
>
>>More specifically I was thinking about periodically switching the 
>>search 
>>to 'prune mode' when the search stagnates or perhaps at a fixed 
>>interval 
>>of 100 generation say. 
>>    
>>
>
>Oh, I understood your thinking.  It just reminded me of those 
>approaches I'd seen in the literature of backprop-trained nets being 
>pruned with EAs.
>
>I haven't seen an approach that uses an EA to alternately complexify, 
>then simplify, but I'd be inclined to think that it would be less 
>efficient than using both dynamics simultaneously.  Dunno, though.
>
>  
>
That's the conclusion I came to - dunno :)  After several thousand 
generations you're probably going to have acquired a lot of connections 
and nodes that aren't contributing to the network fitness and yet they 
are taking up valuable search time - in running the network itself, in 
the comptibilty calculations (longer genomes take longer to compare) and 
in the sexual recombination/reproduction. If you trim away all of that 
'dead-wood' the search should be given a new lease of life. Could be an 
interesting one to investigate.

Colin
